questions.question: For 2024, the maximum employee elective deferral to a 401(k) plan for individuals under age 50 is:
questions.explanation: The 2024 elective deferral limit for 401(k), 403(b), and most 457 plans is $23,000 for participants under age 50. Participants age 50 and over can contribute an additional $7,500 catch-up contribution, for a total of $30,500.

questions.question: The primary tax difference between traditional and Roth IRAs is:

options.B: Traditional contributions are tax-deferred; Roth contributions are after-tax but distributions are tax-free
options.C: Only Roth IRAs allow investments in stocks
options.D: Traditional IRAs cannot be rolled over

questions.explanation: Traditional IRAs provide tax-deductible contributions (subject to limits) with taxable distributions. Roth IRAs use after-tax contributions but provide tax-free qualified distributions. The choice depends on current vs. future tax rates.
questions.tip: Traditional = deduction now, taxed later. Roth = no deduction, tax-free later. Consider future tax rates.

questions.question: For 2024, the maximum IRA contribution for an individual under age 50 is:
questions.explanation: The 2024 IRA contribution limit is $7,000 for individuals under age 50 ($8,000 for those 50 and over). This limit applies across all traditional and Roth IRAs combined. Contributions require earned income.
questions.tip: 2024 IRA: $7,000 + $1,000 catch-up (50+). Combined limit for all IRAs. Need earned income.

questions.question: The penalty for early withdrawal from a traditional IRA before age 59½ is:

options.B: 10% of the taxable distribution

questions.explanation: Early distributions from traditional IRAs and most retirement plans before age 59½ are subject to a 10% additional tax (penalty) on the taxable amount, plus regular income tax. Certain exceptions apply (death, disability, SEPP, first-time home purchase, education, medical expenses).
questions.tip: 10% early withdrawal penalty + regular tax. Many exceptions: disability, SEPP, first home, education, medical.

questions.question: Under SECURE 2.0, required minimum distributions (RMDs) from traditional IRAs must begin at age:
questions.explanation: SECURE 2.0 increased the RMD beginning age to 73 for those born 1951-1959, and to 75 for those born in 1960 or later. RMDs are required from traditional IRAs, SEP IRAs, SIMPLE IRAs, and employer plans (with some exceptions for still-working participants).
questions.tip: RMD age: 73 (born 1951-1959), 75 (born 1960+). First RMD by April 1 of year after reaching age.

questions.question: A SEP IRA is advantageous for small businesses because:

options.B: It has simple administration and allows high employer contributions

questions.explanation: SEP IRAs are simple to establish and administer (no annual Form 5500 filing), allow employer contributions up to 25% of compensation (max $69,000 in 2024), and have flexible contribution amounts each year. Only the employer contributes - no employee deferrals.
questions.tip: SEP = simple setup, no annual filing, employer-only contributions up to 25% of comp (max $69K for 2024).

questions.question: The key difference between defined benefit and defined contribution plans is:

options.A: Only defined benefit plans are tax-qualified
options.B: Defined benefit plans promise a specific retirement benefit; defined contribution plans specify the contribution amount
options.C: Only defined contribution plans allow employer matching
options.D: Defined benefit plans do not allow early distributions

questions.explanation: Defined benefit (DB) plans promise a specific retirement benefit (formula based on salary and years of service), with employer bearing investment risk. Defined contribution (DC) plans specify the contribution amount, with the employee bearing investment risk. Both are tax-qualified.
questions.tip: DB = promised benefit, employer risk. DC = specified contribution, employee risk.

questions.question: An indirect (60-day) rollover requires the distribution to be deposited into an eligible retirement plan within:

options.B: 60 days

questions.explanation: Indirect rollovers require the distribution to be deposited into an eligible retirement plan within 60 days to avoid taxation and penalties. The one-per-year rule applies (one indirect IRA-to-IRA rollover per 12 months). Trustee-to-trustee transfers avoid these limitations.
questions.tip: 60-day rule for indirect rollovers. One per year limit. Direct transfers preferred - no limit.

questions.question: Converting a traditional IRA to a Roth IRA results in:

options.B: Taxation of the converted amount as ordinary income in the year of conversion
options.C: Capital gains treatment on the converted amount
options.D: A 10% penalty on the converted amount

questions.explanation: Roth conversions are taxable events - the converted amount is included in ordinary income in the year of conversion. However, the 10% early withdrawal penalty does not apply to conversions (but applies to earnings withdrawn within 5 years). There are no income limits on conversions.
questions.tip: Roth conversion = taxable income (but no 10% penalty). No income limits on converting. Consider tax bracket.

questions.question: Substantially equal periodic payments (SEPP) from an IRA avoid the 10% early withdrawal penalty if:

options.B: Payments are made annually based on life expectancy
options.C: Payments continue for the longer of 5 years or until age 59½
options.D: Payments are at least $10,000 per year

questions.explanation: SEPP payments (Section 72(t)) must continue for the longer of 5 years OR until the participant reaches age 59½. Three IRS-approved methods calculate payments: required minimum distribution, fixed amortization, and fixed annuitization. Modifying payments prematurely triggers penalties.
questions.tip: SEPP = longer of 5 years or until 59½. Don't modify payments early - triggers back penalties.

questions.question: SIMPLE IRAs are available to employers with no more than:

options.B: 50 employees

questions.explanation: SIMPLE IRAs are available to employers with 100 or fewer employees who earned at least $5,000 in the preceding year. Employers must make either a 2% nonelective contribution or a 3% matching contribution. The 2024 employee contribution limit is $16,000 ($19,500 with catch-up).
questions.tip: SIMPLE = 100 or fewer employees. Required employer contribution (2% or 3% match). $16K employee limit.

questions.question: Employer matching contributions in a 401(k) plan may be subject to:

options.B: A vesting schedule up to 6 years (graded) or 3 years (cliff)

questions.explanation: Employer matching contributions can use 3-year cliff vesting (100% vested after 3 years) or 2-6 year graded vesting. Safe harbor contributions and employee deferrals are always immediately vested. Profit-sharing contributions can use up to 6-year graded or 3-year cliff vesting.
questions.tip: Vesting limits: 3-year cliff or 2-6 year graded. Employee deferrals always 100% vested immediately.

questions.question: The 'backdoor Roth' strategy is used by high-income taxpayers to:

options.B: Contribute to a Roth IRA indirectly through nondeductible traditional IRA contributions and conversion
options.C: Withdraw from Roth IRAs early without penalty
options.D: Receive employer matching in a Roth IRA

questions.explanation: The backdoor Roth allows high-income taxpayers who exceed Roth contribution limits to make nondeductible traditional IRA contributions and then convert to Roth. The pro-rata rule may create taxation if the taxpayer has other pre-tax IRA balances.
questions.tip: Backdoor Roth: nondeductible traditional → convert to Roth. Beware pro-rata rule if you have pre-tax IRAs.

questions.question: Required minimum distributions (RMDs) are calculated by dividing the account balance by:

options.B: A flat factor of 20
options.C: The applicable life expectancy factor from IRS tables

questions.explanation: RMDs are calculated by dividing the December 31 account balance of the prior year by the applicable life expectancy factor from IRS tables (Uniform Lifetime Table for most, Joint and Survivor Table if spouse beneficiary is more than 10 years younger).
questions.tip: RMD = Prior year 12/31 balance ÷ life expectancy factor. Use Uniform Table unless spouse is 10+ years younger.

questions.question: A solo 401(k) allows self-employed individuals to contribute both:

options.A: Employee deferrals and employer profit-sharing contributions
options.B: IRA contributions and SEP contributions

questions.explanation: A solo 401(k) allows self-employed individuals to make employee elective deferrals (up to $23,000 in 2024, plus catch-up) AND employer profit-sharing contributions (up to 25% of net self-employment income), for a combined maximum of $69,000 ($76,500 with catch-up).
questions.tip: Solo 401(k) = employee deferral ($23K) + employer contribution (25% of net SE income). Max $69K total.

questions.question: The net unrealized appreciation (NUA) strategy for employer stock in a 401(k) provides:

options.B: Ordinary income treatment on the cost basis, long-term capital gain treatment on the appreciation
options.C: Deferral of all taxes until the stock is sold

questions.explanation: NUA allows participants to take a lump-sum distribution of employer stock in-kind. Only the cost basis is taxed as ordinary income at distribution. The NUA (appreciation) is taxed as long-term capital gain when the stock is sold, regardless of holding period post-distribution.
questions.tip: NUA: distribute employer stock in-kind. Basis = ordinary income. Appreciation = LTCG (immediate LTCG treatment).

questions.question: 401(k) plans must pass nondiscrimination testing to ensure:

options.A: All employees receive the same compensation
options.B: Highly compensated employees don't benefit disproportionately
options.C: The plan has at least 50 participants

questions.explanation: Nondiscrimination testing (ADP/ACP tests) ensures that highly compensated employees' (HCEs) contributions and benefits don't disproportionately exceed those of non-highly compensated employees. Safe harbor plans can avoid testing by meeting minimum contribution requirements.
questions.tip: ADP/ACP testing prevents HCE favoritism. Safe harbor designs (3% nonelective or 4% match) avoid testing.

questions.question: SECURE Act qualified birth or adoption distributions allow penalty-free withdrawals up to:

options.B: $5,000 per parent, per event

questions.explanation: The SECURE Act allows each parent to withdraw up to $5,000 from retirement accounts within one year of a birth or adoption without the 10% penalty. The withdrawal is still taxable income. The amount can be repaid to the plan for tax-free treatment.
questions.tip: Birth/adoption: up to $5,000 penalty-free per parent per event. Can be repaid to restore tax-deferral.

questions.question: 401(k) plan loans must generally be repaid within:

options.B: 3 years

questions.explanation: 401(k) loans must be repaid within 5 years with substantially level payments at least quarterly. Loans for purchase of a principal residence may have a longer repayment period (often 15 years). Maximum loan is lesser of $50,000 or 50% of vested balance.
questions.tip: 401(k) loan: 5 years max (longer for home). Max $50K or 50% vested. Failure to repay = deemed distribution.

questions.question: A spousal IRA allows a non-working spouse to contribute based on:

options.B: The working spouse's earned income

questions.explanation: Spousal IRAs allow a non-working or low-earning spouse to contribute to an IRA based on the couple's combined earned income (when filing jointly). Both spouses can contribute up to the annual limit if the working spouse has sufficient earned income.
questions.tip: Spousal IRA: non-working spouse can contribute if couple has earned income (MFJ). Full contribution if income covers both.

questions.question: 403(b) plans are available to employees of:

options.B: Public schools, churches, and 501(c)(3) organizations

questions.explanation: 403(b) plans (tax-sheltered annuities) are available to employees of public schools, churches, and tax-exempt 501(c)(3) organizations. Contribution limits and rules are similar to 401(k) plans. Some long-service employees may make additional catch-up contributions.
questions.tip: 403(b) = public schools, churches, 501(c)(3). Similar rules to 401(k). Special catch-up for 15+ year employees.

questions.question: Under SECURE Act rules, most non-spouse beneficiaries who inherit an IRA must:

options.A: Take distributions over their own life expectancy
options.B: Empty the account within 10 years

questions.explanation: The SECURE Act eliminated the stretch IRA for most non-spouse beneficiaries. Designated beneficiaries (individuals other than eligible designated beneficiaries) must empty the inherited IRA within 10 years. Eligible designated beneficiaries (spouses, minor children, disabled/chronically ill, those within 10 years of age) can still stretch.
questions.tip: Post-SECURE: most non-spouse beneficiaries = 10-year rule. EDBs (spouse, minor, disabled) can still stretch.

questions.question: A qualified charitable distribution (QCD) from an IRA allows individuals age 70½ or older to:

options.B: Transfer up to $105,000 directly to charity, satisfying RMDs without increasing AGI
options.D: Avoid all taxation on IRA distributions

questions.explanation: QCDs allow individuals 70½+ to transfer up to $105,000 (2024, indexed) directly from an IRA to qualified charities. The distribution satisfies RMD requirements but isn't included in AGI. This benefits taxpayers who don't itemize or want to reduce AGI for other purposes.
questions.tip: QCD: age 70½+, direct IRA-to-charity, satisfies RMD, excludes from AGI. Max $105K (2024). No itemizing required.

questions.question: Defined benefit plans are attractive for older, high-income business owners because:

options.B: Contributions are based on promised benefit and can be significantly higher than DC limits
options.D: The plans are not subject to ERISA

questions.explanation: Defined benefit plans allow contributions based on actuarial calculations to fund a promised benefit. Older participants need larger contributions to fund the same benefit over a shorter period. This allows contribution amounts that far exceed defined contribution limits.
questions.tip: DB plans: contributions based on promised benefit. Older owners can contribute $200K+ annually in some cases.

questions.question: The pro-rata rule for IRA distributions affects backdoor Roth conversions by:

options.B: Requiring taxation based on the ratio of pre-tax to after-tax funds across all IRAs

questions.explanation: The pro-rata rule treats all traditional, SEP, and SIMPLE IRAs as one account. Conversions are taxed based on the ratio of pre-tax to after-tax funds across all accounts. Those with large pre-tax IRA balances may owe significant tax on backdoor Roth conversions.
questions.tip: Pro-rata rule: can't cherry-pick after-tax funds. All traditional IRAs aggregated. Rollover pre-tax to 401(k) to isolate.

questions.question: The 'mega backdoor Roth' strategy involves:

options.A: Contributing the maximum to multiple Roth IRAs
options.B: Making after-tax 401(k) contributions and converting to Roth
options.C: Using employer matching to fund a Roth account

questions.explanation: The mega backdoor Roth allows employees whose plans permit after-tax contributions (beyond the normal elective deferral limit) to contribute after-tax and convert to Roth (in-plan or via rollover). This can add approximately $46,000 in additional Roth contributions in 2024.
questions.tip: Mega backdoor: after-tax 401(k) → Roth. Requires plan to allow after-tax and in-service distributions/conversions.

questions.question: For Roth IRA distributions to be qualified (tax-free), the account must be open for:

options.A: 3 years and the owner must be 55
options.B: 5 years and the owner must be 59½ (or meet another exception)
options.D: Any period if only contributions are withdrawn

questions.explanation: Qualified Roth distributions require the 5-year holding period to be satisfied AND the distribution must be made after age 59½, death, disability, or first-time home purchase ($10,000 limit). Contributions can always be withdrawn tax-free, but earnings require qualified distribution status.
questions.tip: Qualified Roth: 5 years AND 59½ (or death, disability, first home). Contributions always tax-free. Earnings need both requirements.

questions.question: A retirement plan is top-heavy when more than what percentage of benefits accrues to key employees?
questions.explanation: A plan is top-heavy when more than 60% of the aggregate account balances (DC) or present value of accrued benefits (DB) belongs to key employees (officers earning over $220,000 in 2024, 5%+ owners, 1%+ owners earning over $150,000). Top-heavy plans must provide minimum contributions to non-key employees.
questions.tip: Top-heavy = >60% to key employees. Requires minimum 3% contribution to non-key employees.

questions.question: A cash balance plan is a type of defined benefit plan that:

options.A: Provides participants with a lump sum at retirement only
options.B: Expresses benefits in terms of a hypothetical account balance that grows with contributions and interest credits
options.C: Is funded entirely by employee contributions

questions.explanation: Cash balance plans are defined benefit plans that express benefits as a hypothetical account balance. Each year, the account receives a pay credit (% of salary) and an interest credit (guaranteed rate). This hybrid structure combines DB tax advantages with DC-like portability.
questions.tip: Cash balance = DB with account-like appearance. Pay credits + interest credits. Employer bears investment risk.

questions.question: The still-working exception to RMDs allows participants to delay employer plan RMDs if:

options.A: They continue working for any employer
options.B: They continue working for the employer sponsoring the plan and don't own more than 5%

questions.explanation: Participants who continue working past RMD age can delay RMDs from their current employer's plan until they retire (if they don't own more than 5% of the company). This doesn't apply to IRAs or plans from former employers. 5%+ owners cannot use this exception.
questions.tip: Still-working exception: current employer plan only, <5% owner. Doesn't apply to IRAs or former employer plans.

questions.question: Excess contributions to an IRA are subject to an annual penalty of:
questions.explanation: Excess IRA contributions are subject to a 6% excise tax per year until corrected. The penalty can be avoided by withdrawing the excess (plus earnings) before the tax filing deadline (including extensions). Excess contributions in one year can be absorbed by under-contributing in future years.
questions.tip: 6% annual penalty on excess contributions. Withdraw before filing deadline to avoid. Can apply to future years.

questions.question: Nonqualified deferred compensation plans differ from qualified plans in that:

options.A: They have no contribution limits but provide no current deduction and aren't protected from employer creditors
options.B: They are available to all employees
options.D: They are protected in employer bankruptcy

questions.explanation: Nonqualified deferred compensation (NQDC) plans have no contribution limits but: (1) employer gets no deduction until employee receives payment, (2) assets are subject to employer creditors (not in a trust), (3) can discriminate in favor of executives. Section 409A imposes strict deferral election and distribution timing rules.
questions.tip: NQDC: no limits, but no current deduction, no creditor protection, strict 409A rules. Executive benefit vehicle.

questions.question: When a defined contribution plan terminates, participants must:

options.B: Receive distributions or roll over their vested account balances

questions.explanation: Upon plan termination, participants become 100% vested in their account balances and must receive distributions. They can take a lump sum (taxable), roll over to an IRA or another employer plan, or purchase an annuity. The employer must follow IRS and DOL termination procedures.
questions.tip: Plan termination = 100% vesting. Participants receive/rollover. Follow IRS/DOL procedures.

questions.question: After the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, recharacterization of Roth conversions:

options.B: Is no longer permitted
options.C: Is permitted only for amounts under $50,000

questions.explanation: TCJA eliminated the ability to recharacterize Roth conversions (the 'do-over' provision). Conversions from traditional to Roth are now irrevocable. However, recharacterization of regular IRA contributions (traditional to Roth or vice versa) is still permitted before the filing deadline.
questions.tip: Can't recharacterize Roth conversions (post-TCJA). Can still recharacterize contributions before filing deadline.

questions.question: The 'Rule of 55' allows penalty-free distributions from:

options.B: An employer plan if the participant separates from service in or after the year they turn 55
options.C: All retirement accounts after 55 years of contributions

questions.explanation: The Rule of 55 allows penalty-free distributions from a 401(k) or 403(b) if the participant separates from service in or after the year they turn 55 (age 50 for public safety employees). This applies only to the plan of the employer from which they separated, not IRAs or prior employer plans.
questions.tip: Rule of 55: penalty-free from current employer plan if separate at 55+. Doesn't apply to IRAs or old employer plans.
